content.description: While working with individuals who have a spider phobia, Dr. Nielsen wants to determine whether exposing them to spiders will reduce their fears. Dr. Nielsen asks one participant to watch a ten-minute video about spiders and report the anxiety they experienced on a ten-point scale (1 equals "not at all anxious," and 10 equals “extremely anxious”) every two minutes. The data Dr. Nielsen obtained from the participant are presented in the graph.
content.question: Based on the graph, which of the following conclusions can be drawn about the effectiveness of this approach?

choices.label: There is a positive correlation between exposure to spiders and anxiety.
There is a statistically significant difference between exposure to spiders and anxiety.
The optimal time of exposure to spiders for reducing anxiety is 8 minutes.
There is a negative correlation between length of time exposed to spiders and anxiety ratings.

content.answer: There is a negative correlation between length of time exposed to spiders and anxiety ratings.
